fields.value: Big Allied and Dangerous (BAAD) Database 1 - Lethality Data, 1998-2005

authorAffiliation.value: University at Albany, State University of New York. Rockefeller College of Public Affairs & Policy. Assistant Professor of Political Science.
University at Albany, State University of New York. Rockefeller College of Public Affairs & Policy. Assistant Professor of Public Administration & Policy.
University at Albany, State University of New York. Rockefeller College of Public Affairs & Policy. Project on Violent Conflict. Research Director.

dsDescriptionValue.value:
BAAD seeks to create a comprehensive database of terrorist organizations. The database contains information on organizational level variables such as ideology, location, size, structure, and funding as well as network data on variables such as allies, rivals, targets, and state sponsors. The data were retrieved from MIPT's Terrorism Knowledge Base, Correlates of War (COW), Polity,
and Polity2.

publicationCitation.value: Asal, V. H. & Rethemeyer, R. K. (2008). Dilettantes, Ideologues and the Weak: Terrorists Who Don’t Kill. Conflict Management and Peace Science, 25(3), 244-263.
Asal, V. H. & Rethemeyer, R. K. (2008). Dilettantes, Ideologues and the Weak: Terrorists Who Don’t Kill. Conflict Management and Peace Science, 25(3), 244-263.
Asal, V. H. & Rethemeyer, R. K. (2008). The Nature of the Beast: Terrorist: The Organizational and Network Characteristics of Organizational Lethality. Journal of Politics, 70(2), 437-449.

fields.value: Subject: Study Level Error Note, Notes: The study uses primarily media sources, which could vary in their definition of a terrorist attack, and in their data collection methods. The study only accounted for slightly more than half of all fatalities attributed to acts of terrorism between 1998 and 2005. The other significant number of fatalities are acts that went unclaimed, either by terrorist organizations in the database, unknown terrorist entities, or terrorists entities not classified as organizations by the database and therefore would not be part of the study. Also some organizations may have been excluded because they were deemed religious in nature. This would mean the findings on religion and lethality are understated. Finally, of the 499 organizations that committed an act, MIPT had no information or information that could be duplicative on 104 of the organizations, leaving the possibility of inaccurate data.;

value: Active terrorist organizations operating worldwide from 1998-2005.

fields.value: For BAAD Lethality, the data were collected on terrorist organizations active worldwide. This included both international and domestic organizations, active in the 1998-2005 time period. Historical data collection was based originally off of the Memorial Institute for the Prevention of Terrorism’s (MIPT) Terrorism Knowledge Base (TKB).                                                                                                                                   For each organization, coders read the organization’s page and extracted information on its size (in terms of number of members), date of founding, ideology, sources of sponsorship, country the organization primarily targets, number of connections to other terrorist organizations, and the scope of the territory the group is purported to control. If information in the page was contradictory or if MIPT’s data was contradicted by other sources, independent confirmation was sought from academic, internet, and print media resources before assigning a final code or value for a variable.
